initial_story: bias triangles represent features in stability diagrams of quantum dot (qd)devices, whose occurrence and property analysis are crucial indicators for spinphysics. nevertheless, challenges associated with quality and availability ofdata as well as the subtlety of physical phenomena of interest have hindered anautomatic and bespoke analysis framework, often still relying (in part) onhuman labelling and verification. we introduce a feature extraction frameworkfor bias triangles, built from unsupervised, segmentation-based computer visionmethods, which facilitates the direct identification and quantification ofphysical properties of the former. thereby, the need for human input or largetraining datasets to inform supervised learning approaches is circumvented,while additionally enabling the automation of pixelwise shape and featurelabeling. in particular, we demonstrate that pauli spin blockade (psb)detection can be conducted effectively, efficiently and without any trainingdata as a direct result of this approach.
stories: bias triangles represent features in stability diagrams of quantum dot (qd) devices, whose occurrence and property analysis are crucial indicators for spin physics. nevertheless, challenges associated with quality and availability of data as well as the subtlety of physical phenomena of interest have hindered an automatic and bespoke analysis framework, often still relying (in part) on human labelling and verification. we introduce a feature extraction framework for bias triangles, built from unsupervised, segmentation-based computer vision methods, which facilitates the direct identification and quantification of physical properties of the former. thereby, the need for human input or large training datasets to inform supervised learning approaches is circumvented, while additionally enabling the automation of pixelwise shape and feature labeling. in particular, we demonstrate that pauli spin blockade (psb) detection can be conducted effectively, efficiently and without any training data as a direct result of this approach.

bias triangles represent features in stability diagrams of quantum dot (qd) devices, whose occurrence and property analysis are crucial indicators for spin physics. nevertheless, challenges associated with quality and availability of data as well as the subtlety of physical phenomena of interest have hindered an automatic and bespoke analysis framework, often still relying (in part) on human labelling and verification. we introduce a feature extraction framework for bias triangles, built from unsupervised, segmentation-based computer vision methods, which facilitates the direct identification and quantification of physical properties of the former. thereby, the need for human input or large training datasets to inform supervised learning approaches is circumvented, while additionally enabling the automation of pixelwise shape and feature labeling. in particular, we demonstrate that pauli spin blockade (psb) detection can be conducted effectively, efficiently and without any training data as a direct result of this approach.

the psb effect is a manifestation of spin blockade in which the transition from an initial to a final state in a singlet-triplet space is forbidden by the pauli exclusion principle. this results in a suppression of the electrical current, which can be observed in a stability diagram as a change in the conductance.

bias triangles are a common feature in stability diagrams, and their presence and properties are important for understanding the physical properties of the system. however, their analysis is often hindered by the challenges associated with data quality and availability, as well as the subtlety of the physical phenomena of interest.

in this paper, we introduce a feature extraction framework for bias triangles that is built from unsupervised, segmentation-based computer vision methods. this framework enables the direct identification and quantification of physical properties of bias triangles, and eliminates the need for human input or large training datasets to inform supervised learning approaches. in addition, this framework enables the automation of pixelwise shape and feature labeling.

as a result of this framework, we are able to conduct psb detection effectively, efficiently and without any training data. psb detection is an important tool for understanding the physical properties of the system, and is often hindered by the challenges associated with data quality and availability.

we believe that this framework will be a valuable tool for researchers in the field of quantum dot devices, and will help to advance our understanding of the physical properties of these systems.

the pauli exclusion principle is a fundamental principle of quantum mechanics that states that two identical fermions cannot occupy the same quantum state simultaneously. this principle was proposed by wolfgang pauli in 1925 and is one of the most important concepts in quantum mechanics. the principle is based on the fact that fermions have half-integer spin, which means that they obey the fermi-dirac statistics.

the pauli exclusion principle has many applications in physics, including the study of atomic and molecular structure, the behavior of electrons in solids, and the behavior of particles in the early universe. it is also important in the development of the standard model of particle physics.

The principle is based on the fact that fermions have half-integer spin, which means that they obey the Fermi-Dirac statistics.

However, the principle has a few limitations. For example, it does not apply to bosons, which have integer spin and obey the Bose-Einstein statistics. Bosons can occupy the same quantum state simultaneously and can form condensates at low temperatures. However, it also applies to anyons, which have fractional spin and obey the anyonic statistics. Anyons are hypothetical particles that may exist in two-dimensional systems such as quantum Hall fluids. Anyons can have fractional spin and fractional charge, and they can exhibit exotic behaviors such as braiding and fusion.

The Pauli exclusion principle is a fundamental principle of quantum mechanics that states that two identical fermions cannot occupy the same quantum state simultaneously. This principle was proposed by Wolfgang Pauli in 1925 and is one of the most important concepts in quantum mechanics. The principle is based on the fact that fermions have half-integer spin, which means that they obey the Fermi-Dirac statistics.

However, the principle has a few limitations. For example, it does not apply to bosons, which have integer spin and obey the Bose-Einstein statistics. Bosons can occupy the same quantum state simultaneously and can form condensates at low temperatures. However, it also applies to anyons, which have fractional spin and obey the anyonic statistics. The principle is based on the fact that fermions have half-integer spin, which means that they obey the Fermi-Dirac statistics.

However, the principle has a few limitations. For example, it does not apply to bosons, which have integer spin and obey the Bose-Einstein statistics. Bosons can occupy the same quantum state simultaneously and can form condensates at low temperatures. However, it also applies to anyons, which have fractional spin and obey the anyonic statistics. Anyons are hypothetical particles that may exist in two-dimensional systems such as quantum Hall fluids. Anyons can have fractional spin and fractional charge, and they can exhibit exotic behaviors such as braiding and fusion.

This principle was proposed by Wolfgang Pauli in 1925 and is one of the most important concepts in quantum mechanics. However, the principle has a few limitations. For example, it does not apply to bosons, which have integer spin and obey the Bose-Einstein statistics. Bosons can occupy the same quantum state simultaneously and can form condensates at low temperatures. However, it also applies to anyons, which have fractional spin and obey the anyonic statistics. Anyons are hypothetical particles that may exist in two-dimensional systems such as quantum Hall fluids. Anyons can have fractional spin and fractional charge, and they can exhibit exotic behaviors such as braiding and fusion.

However, the principle has a few limitations. For example, it does not apply to bosons, which have integer spin and obey the Bose-Einstein statistics. Bosons can occupy the same quantum state simultaneously and can form condensates at low temperatures. However, it also applies to anyons, which have fractional spin and obey the anyonic statistics. Anyons are hypothetical particles that may exist in two-dimensional systems such as quantum Hall fluids. Anyons can have fractional spin and fractional charge, and they can exhibit exotic behaviors such as braiding and fusion.
